Group.title: IPv6
Group.description: The system includes support for Internet Protocol version 6. A major and often-mentioned improvement over IPv4 is its enormous increase in the number of available addresses. Another important feature is its support for automatic configuration of many network settings.

Group.title: Disable Support for IPv6 unless Needed
Group.description: Despite configuration that suggests support for IPv6 has been disabled, link-local IPv6 address autoconfiguration occurs even when only an IPv4 address is assigned. The only way to effectively prevent execution of the IPv6 networking stack is to instruct the IPv6 kernel module not to load it.

Rule.title: Disable IPv6 Networking Support Automatic Loading
Rule.description: To prevent the IPv6 kernel module (ipv6) from loading the IPv6 networking stack, add the following line to /etc/modprobe.d/disabled.conf (or another file in /etc/modprobe.d): options ipv6 disable=1 This permits the IPv6 module to be loaded (and thus satisfy other modules that depend on it), while disabling support for the IPv6 protocol.
Rule.rationale: Any networking stack, including IPv6, that does not need to be active should be disabled in order to reduce the system's vulnerability to exploitation of any implementation flaws.

Group.title: Disable Support for RPC IPv6 unless Needed
Group.description: RPC services for NFSv4 try to load transport modules for udp6 and tcp6 by default, even if IPv6 has been disabled in /etc/modprobe.d. To prevent RPC services such as rpc.mountd from attempting to start IPv6 network listeners, remove or comment out the following two lines in /etc/netconfig: udp6 tpi_clts v inet6 udp - - tcp6 tpi_cots_ord v inet6 tcp - -

Rule.title: Disable RPC IPv6 Network Listeners
Rule.description: RPC IPv6 network listeners should be disabled.

Group.title: Configure IPv6 Settings if Necessary
Group.description: A major feature of IPv6 is the extent to which systems implementing it can automatically configure their networking devices using information from the network. From a security perspective, manually configuring important configuration information is always preferable to accepting it from the network in an unauthenticated fashion.

Group.title: Disable Automatic Configuration
Group.description: Disable the system's acceptance of router advertisements and redirects by adding or correcting the following line in /etc/sysconfig/network (note that this does not disable sending router solicitations): IPV6_AUTOCONF=no

Value.title: IPV6_AUTOCONF
Value.description: Toggle global IPv6 autoconfiguration (only, if global forwarding is disabled)

Rule.title: Disable Accepting IPv6 Router Advertisements
Rule.description: The default setting for accepting IPv6 router advertisements should be: for all interfaces.

Rule.title: Disable Accepting IPv6 Redirects
Rule.description: Accepting redirects from IPv6 routers should be: for all interfaces.
